title: 113_hr4831
content: The Act may be cited as the "Twenty-First Century Manufacturing Skills and Jobs Act of 2014". It includes provisions for federal matching payments for state new manufacturing jobs training tax credits. The Secretary of the Treasury will make quarterly payments to eligible community colleges based on new manufacturing job withholding matches. Eligible trainees will receive a match from participating manufacturing employers. Eligible community colleges must primarily award 2-year associate's degrees that transfer to a bachelor's degree. The State new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program allows eligible community colleges and manufacturing employers to sign a contract for training tax credits. The program ensures that State income taxes withheld by the employer for the trainee's qualified training costs are remitted to the community college. The program allows eligible community colleges and manufacturing employers to sign a contract for training tax credits. State income taxes withheld by the employer for the trainee's training costs are remitted to the community college as payment for education provided. The contract must meet all applicable requirements under the State program. The eligible community college will provide qualified training to individuals designated by the employer, without charging tuition or fees. The employer must hire these individuals for full-time employment at a job site within the State, paying them a wage that is at least 175 percent of the Federal minimum wage. Additionally, the employer will remit State income taxes as specified under the State program. The employer will remit State income taxes withheld on behalf of the individual to the community college for training, not exceeding the specified cost. The contract must outline the total cost of training, including equipment and materials, which must be reasonable by market standards. Qualified training refers to education or skills necessary for the job or obtaining required licenses. The State program requires individuals to have the necessary license, certificate, or credential for the job they will be employed in. The job must be a new position for eligibility in the State new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program. The State program requires individuals to have the necessary license, certificate, or credential for a new job that results in a net increase in employment for the employer, excluding recalled, replacement, or existing jobs within the past year. Only U.S. employees are considered for eligibility. The State program requires individuals to have the necessary license, certificate, or credential for a new job that results in a net increase in employment for the employer, excluding recalled, replacement, or existing jobs within the past year. Only U.S. employees are considered for eligibility. An employer or eligible community college participating in a State new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program may work with local workforce investment boards to hire and train eligible trainees who received qualified training through the program. The manufacturing jobs training tax credit program applies to full-time employees working at eligible manufacturing employers in the same state as the community college, meeting wage and job requirements. Eligible employers must be engaged in manufacturing within the U.S. in specific industrial sectors. The manufacturing jobs training tax credit program appropriates necessary funds from the Treasury to carry out the program. Withheld State income tax remitted to eligible community colleges for training is not treated as employer expenses for tax purposes. Payments with respect to eligible trainees are also not subject to State income tax treatment. The manufacturing jobs training tax credit program appropriates funds from the Treasury. Payments made to eligible trainees are treated as income and for tax deduction purposes under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
